messages.subject: Metal same!?!
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, I bought myself a katana, which Barry has very kindly taken his time to discuss it with me. Thank you Barry! I was suggested that I should see if the
messages.messageBody:
Hi all,
I bought myself a katana, which Barry has very kindly taken his time to
discuss it with me.
Thank you Barry!
I was suggested that I should see if the people on the list might give
some information about the metal same which is fitted on the tsuka. I
would like any information you might be willing to share.

Single picture (for dialers)
http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/images/Koshirae1/Tsuka1B.jpg

Many picures (for you that are interested in the other fittings)
http://hem.bredband.net/odrike/Koshirae1.htm

Regards,
Fredrik

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] NTHK origami
messages.msgSnippet: Could be a shop paper, the name rings a bell, have you spoken to Chris Bowen about it ?. Rich ... -- Richard Turner Nihontô Message Board
messages.messageBody:
Could be a shop paper, the name rings a bell, have you spoken to Chris
Bowen about it ?.

Rich

Barry Thomas wrote:

> Well, sighhhhhh, we have people in Australia (i.e., gaijin) who issue
> their own
> "papers" with swords they sell. It could be a complete put-up job
> from anywhere
> in the West, desu ne??? Or a similar "operation" from anybody in
> Japan who
> fancies themselves as "sensei"... The advent of high resolution
> colour printers
> (COLOUR guys) has made this so much easier. This is all a very polite
> way of
> saying that some people consider themselves Legends in their own
> Lunchtime!!!
> As for us, despite papers we still should run with our instincts as to
> quality.
>
> Oh, I still like the tsuba and would have it for curiosity value. I
> think I
> know who will end up with it (snigger snigger...)
>
> Barry Thomas.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] NTHK origami
messages.msgSnippet: Well, sighhhhhh, we have people in Australia (i.e., gaijin) who issue their own papers with swords they sell.  It could be a complete put-up job from
messages.messageBody:
Well, sighhhhhh, we have people in Australia (i.e., gaijin) who issue their own
"papers" with swords they sell. It could be a complete put-up job from anywhere
in the West, desu ne??? Or a similar "operation" from anybody in Japan who
fancies themselves as "sensei"... The advent of high resolution colour printers
(COLOUR guys) has made this so much easier. This is all a very polite way of
saying that some people consider themselves Legends in their own Lunchtime!!!
As for us, despite papers we still should run with our instincts as to quality.

Oh, I still like the tsuba and would have it for curiosity value. I think I
know who will end up with it (snigger snigger...)

Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: "Gordon Robson" <robsongo@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Sunday, June 19, 2005 2:04 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] NTHK origami


Never heard of them.

Gordon

> Thats one of the small country kantei groups is it not ?, south of
> Tokyo
> somewhere, or am I confusing them with another group. Gordon R may know
> who they are.
>
> Rich
>
> Jim Gilbert wrote:
>
>> David,
>> The kanteisho is from the Nihon Tosogu Kenkyu Kai, dated Heisei 17.
>>
>> Does anyone have a contact in that organization?
>>
>> Jim

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] NTHK origami
messages.msgSnippet: David, The kanteisho is from the Nihon Tosogu Kenkyu Kai, dated Heisei 17. Does anyone have a contact in that organization? Jim I have an NTHK origami on which
messages.messageBody:
David,
The kanteisho is from the Nihon Tosogu Kenkyu Kai, dated Heisei 17.

Does anyone have a contact in that organization?

Jim




I have an NTHK origami on which the ink of many of the characters has fallen off, making it hard(er) to read. I do not know which NTHK this one is from. It is for a tsuba, and is numbered 205008. Can one contact the NTHK (of one of which I am a member) and obtain from them a replacement?

David Zincavage

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
